claim: In Germany, France, and Switzerland, you pay with euros.

supporting.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all located in Europe, where the euro is the official currency in many countries.

attacks.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all located in Europe, where the euro is the official currency in many countries.
Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc (CHF) as its official currency, not the euro.
While Switzerland is not in the Eurozone, some border regions and businesses may accept euros for convenience, though change is often given in francs.

supporting.text: Germany and France are members of the Eurozone, where the euro is the official currency.

attacks.text: Germany and France are members of the Eurozone, where the euro is the official currency.
Switzerland is not a member of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency.
While Switzerland is not in the Eurozone, many businesses in border regions and tourist areas accept euros, though change is often given in Swiss francs.

supporting.text: Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.

attacks.text: Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.
While Switzerland uses the Swiss franc, many businesses near the border accept euros for convenience, especially in tourist areas.
Acceptance of euros in Switzerland is unofficial and often comes with poor exchange rates, reinforcing that the Swiss franc remains the official and dominant currency.
Some international transactions in Switzerland may be conducted in euros due to global trade practices.
Such transactions are exceptions and do not reflect standard domestic currency usage, which is strictly the Swiss franc.

supporting.text: While some businesses in Switzerland may accept euros, the legal tender is the Swiss franc, not the euro.

attacks.text: While some businesses in Switzerland may accept euros, the legal tender is the Swiss franc, not the euro.
Many tourist-heavy areas in Switzerland widely accept euros, making it functionally usable despite not being legal tender.
Even if euros are accepted, businesses often give change in Swiss francs, complicating transactions for tourists.
Cross-border regions like Basel or Geneva frequently use euros due to proximity to Eurozone countries.
Such regions are exceptions, and the Swiss National Bank enforces franc usage for official transactions.
